newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: ABN in no hurry to spend MeesPierson cash.
newsitem.headline: ABN in no hurry to spend MeesPierson cash.

text.p: Dutch bank ABN AMRO NV said the imminent sale of its Dutch investment banking unit MeesPierson would not lead to an acceleration in acquisition activity.
"The money is not burning a hole in our pocket and we don't feel we have to spend it immediately," executive board chairman Jan Kalff told reporters on Friday.
Kalff was addressing a news conference on ABN AMRO's planned $1.95 billion acquisition of Standard Federal Bancorp.
ABN AMRO is negotiating the sale of MeesPierson to Belgian/Dutch financial group Fortis AMEV.AS and analysts say the deal could raise up to 2.5 billion guilders.
"The sale of MeesPierson is completely unrelated to any kind of acquisition whatsoever," Kalff said.
Kalff said ABN AMRO would continue to pursue growth of its international banking activities and specifically mentioned investment banking and asset management in this context.

As far as the U.S. was concerned, he said the three states into which ABN AMRO was moving with the planned Standard Federal buy -- Michigan, Ohio and Indiana -- would be the most likely areas for further expansion in the future.
"The best opportunities are those which are close at hand," he said, but he added that a fresh acquisition was unlikely to materialise in this region in the short term.
